# Welcome 
Rock climbing is more than just a sport. It is a way for us to overcome fears, 
strengthen our bodies and minds, discover spectacular places around the 
world, and interact with human beings from all walks of life. It can be 
humbling when you discover your initial limitations, but also empowering when 
you discover how you and your body are capable of going beyond them. All these 
aspects combine to create a pursuit that is addicting and often life changing.

On the north coast of Taiwan is Long Dong, one of the world's most 
spectacular sandstone sea-cliff climbing areas. There are are over five hundred 
routes for all skill and interest levels, ranging from short routes of pure 
movement to full-on one day adventures. The area is about 90 minutes from 
Taipei by bus and is near the small fishing village of Hemei. 

"Climbing is a game in which we play at learning the skills necessary to a 
beautiful life" -Royal Robbins, Yosemite climbing legend. 

Whether you've traveled around the world in search of beautiful rock or never 
before worn climbing shoes, our programs will inspire a connection with a 
magical and powerful art form in a truly awesome part of the world. 

## Climbing Packages

### For Beginning Climbers 

Indoor Package: This is a tour of what climbing is all about. You will learn to 
tie basic knots, general safety, and elementary technique. This set of courses 
is ideal for anyone eager to learn about climbing, but cannot commit an entire 
day to climbing outdoors. 

Courses included: Introduction to Climbing (Artificial Wall), Movement Practice 
(Artificial Wall), Lead Climbing (Artificial Wall).

Day Trip to Long Dong: Meet at Taipei Main station's West bus terminal in the 
morning. Students can choose from a range of courses ranging from beginner 
to advanced. Healthy snacks are included, afternoon swimming is optional, 
and we will return to Taipei in the evening. 

Courses included: Introduction to Climbing (Natural Rock), Movement Practice 
(Natural Rock).

Weekend Trip to Long Dong: This trip includes an overnight stay to maximize 
climbing and enjoyment. We will camp in one of LD's namesake caves. A simple 
dinner and breakfast are also included. Staying in the local hostel is also an 
option, but will require an additional fee.  

Courses included: Introduction to Climbing (Natural Rock), Movement Practice 
(Natural Rock), Simple Anchors and Rappelling, Lead Climbing (Natural 
Rock), Lead Climbing Practice.

Our beginner packages are designed for you to become as self-sufficient as 
soon as possible, so you can get on with what you really want to do: climb! 
We are, however, committed to your safety and comfort, so we provide 
extra care and attention as you require it. 

### For Experienced Climbers

Traditional Climbing Bonanza- The large sandstone blocks that make up Long 
Dong lend themselves perfectly for traditional climbing. Almost all of the 
climbs can be done by placing protection instead of using the drilled bolts. 
We offer courses for those who have never placed gear, advanced technique, 
as well as day or multi-day guiding. 

Courses included: Traditional Gear Placement, Leading Traditional Climbs, 
Traditional Climbing Practice, Traditional Gear Anchors
 
### For Traveling Climbers

Discover the culture and astounding natural beauty of Taiwan. Explore Long 
Dong and other gems of the Isla Formosa's mountains, beaches, and towns
with us. We can arrange anything from a quick day trip, to week long 
adventures. For the autonomous traveler, we offer gear rental (harnesses, 
draws rope, shoes, protection) and assistance with transportation 
information.

For a detailed listing of courses, please see the course catalog below.

## Your Guides

Ming has dedicated a large portion of his life to climbing since returning to 
Taiwan ten years ago. He has spent nearly every weekend at Long Dong or 
scouting for new areas around the island.  During that time he was mentored 
intensely by some of the finest local and international climbers ever to visit 
Taiwan. He learned such difficult and subtle crafts as the use of traditional 
gear, how to climb safely (i.e. how and when to chicken out), and how to drink 
copious amounts of alcohol at the end of a climbing day to celebrate still 
being alive.  Now he feels ready to share this knowledge and the life-changing 
experience of climbing at Long Dong.  

Ana began her climbing addiction in Yangshuo, China -Asia's largest sport 
climbing area. As the addiction set in, she abandoned a conventional career 
on a quest to learn as much as possible from the legends around her. She has
worked as a guide leading school groups and individuals on caving, climbing, 
and kayaking adventures. She came to Taiwan after hearing rumors of the 
glorious sea stacks and has made it her mission to spend as much time as 
possible at Long Dong or exploring Taiwan's other climbing potential. Since 
being in Taiwan, she has been seen ascending many a classic LD route 
seemingly effortlessly.
   
# Course Catalog

### Introduction to Climbing (Artificial Wall)

Description: This is a first course in climbing. Students will learn basic 
climbing safety, such as how to identify general hazards in their chosen 
climbing environment, how to evaluate and mitigate risk, how to tie in with a 
figure 8 knot, and how to belay a top-roped climber. Basic movement 
technique over vertical terrain will also be demonstrated. Students will have 
the opportunity to complete 2 top-rope climbs. Since this course is presented 
in an artificial environment, students are encouraged to seek out additional 
instruction in order to climb in a natural environment, such as the courses 
offered below.  

Course Topics: Risk Management. Tying in. Top-rope Belay. Movement 
Technique.

Duration: Approximately 2 hrs.

Location: Fuhe Bridge Tower or Nangang Sports Center

Enrollment: Maximum 3 people

Prerequisites: None

### Movement Practice (Artificial Wall)
Description: Students will learn more advanced techniques for movement in a 
vertical environment such as how to negotiate different types of terrain from 
low-angle slab to steep overhangs and roofs, how to use different handholds 
such as sidepulls, underclings, crimps, slopers, pinches, pockets, how to 
use their feet well, i.e smearing, edging, stemming, matching, hooking and 
flagging.  Students will then be presented with a variety of routes to challenge 
their movement ability, completing a minimum of two top-rope climbs or a set 
of 5 problems.

Course Topics: Negotiating various types of terrain. Advanced Foot 
Technique. Various Handholds.

Duration: 1 hr.

Location: Fuhe Bridge Tower, Nangang Sports Center or GongGuan 
               Bouldering Wall

Enrollment: Maximum 3 people

Prerequisites: None

### Lead Climbing (Artificial Wall)
Description: This course will help you discover what it takes to become a 
leader in climbing, take control of your own climbing experience, and grow to 
be an autonomous and responsible climber. Students will learn how to 
identify generals hazards of leading, how to assess risk while on lead, how to 
set up a stance for clipping, and proper clipping technique.Sometimes leaders 
must lead from behind as well, so the essentials of lead belaying will be 
covered. Students will then have the opportunity to lead 2 climbs and belay at 
least 1 lead climb to integrate all the skills necessary to be a good leader. 
Students completing this course or who have the equivalent experience are 
still strongly encouraged to take Lead Climbing (Natural Rock) before they 
attempt to lead outside.

Course Topics: Risk Assessment. Proper Quickdraw Usage. Lead Belay.

Duration: 2 hours

Location: Fuhe Bridge Tower or Nangang Sports Center

Enrollment: Maximum 3 people

Prerequisites: Introduction to Climbing or equivalent, 
                     Movement Practice

### Introduction to Climbing (Natural Rock) 
Description: This is a first course in climbing outside. Students will learn 
basic climbing safety, such as how to identify general hazards in their chosen 
climbing environment, how to evaluate and mitigate of risk, how to tie in with a 
figure 8 knot, and belaying essentials. Basic movement technique over 
vertical terrain will also be demonstrated. Students will have the opportunity 
to complete 2 top-rope climbs. Students that have completed the indoor 
course or have the equivalent experience may take a review version of
this course, if it fits their needs and learning style.

Course Topics: Risk Management. Tying in. Top-rope Belay. Movement 
Technique.

Duration: Approximately 3 hrs.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Minimum 3 people, Maximum 5 people.

Prerequisites: None

### Movement Practice (Natural Rock)
Description: Students will learn more advanced techniques for movement in a 
vertical environment such as how to negotiate different types of terrain from 
low-angle slab to steep overhangs and roofs, how to use different handholds 
such as sidepulls, underclings, crimps, slopers, pinches, pockets, how to 
use their feet well, i.e smearing, edging, stemming, matching, hooking and 
flagging.  Students will then be presented with a variety of routes to challenge 
their movement ability, completing a minimum of two top-rope climbs or a set 
of 5 problems. Students who have completed the indoor courses are still 
encouraged to engage in this course fully, as movement over rock is vastly 
different than movement in an artificial environment. 
 
Course Topics: Negotiating various types of terrain. Advanced Foot 
Technique. Various Handholds.

Duration: Approximately 3 hrs.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Minimum 3 people, Maximum 5 people.

Prerequisites: Introduction to Climbing (Natural Rock) or equivalent.

### Simple Anchors and Rappelling
Description: What do you do after you finish a climb? This class teaches the
basics of anchoring yourself safely, i.e. how to build and take apart  simple 
anchors. Then you will learn how use the rope to exit off a climb safely and 
self-sufficiently.  

Course Topics: Setting Toprope Anchors. Cleaning Toprope Anchors. 
Rappelling.  Autoblock. Fireman's Belay.

Duration: 1 hour

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Minimum 3 people, Maximum 5 people.

Prerequisites: Introduction to Climbing (Natural Rock) or equivalent.

### Lead Climbing (Natural Rock)
Description: This course will help you discover what it takes to become a 
leader in climbing, take control of your own climbing experience, and grow to 
be an autonomous and responsible climber. Students will learn how to 
identify generals hazards of leading, how to assess risk while on lead, how to 
set up a stance for clipping, and proper clipping technique. Sometimes leaders 
must lead from behind as well, so the essentials of lead belaying will be 
covered. Students will then have the opportunity to lead 2 climbs and belay at 
least 1 lead climb to integrate all the skills necessary to be a good leader. 

Course Topics: Risk Assessment. Proper Quickdraw Usage. Lead Belay.
Bolt Safety and Ethics. Simple Recovery and Retreating Techniques. 2 Lead 
Climbs.

Duration: 3 hrs.

Location: Long Dong 

Enrollment: Maximum 4 people.

Prerequisites: Introduction to Climbing (Natural Rock) or equivalent, 
                     Simple Anchors and Rappelling, 
                     Movement Practice (Natural Rock)

### Lead Climbing Practice (Natural Rock)
Description: This practice session fosters greater comfort and confidence while 
leading on natural rock. It includes more movement practice. Students have the 
opportunity to apply the techniques for safe clipping, retreating, and cleaning in 
a minimum of 2 lead climbs.

Duration: 3 hours

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 3 people.

Prerequisites: Lead Climbing (natural rock) or equivalent 

### Traditional Gear Placement
Description: Placing traditional gear is a fine craft. This course imparts the 
fundamentals from first principles in physics. Students will practice in a 
thorough and intensive hands-on session on the ground.  Then students 
will then have the opportunity to follow and observe the placements on 
two traditional climbs.

Course Topics: Fundamentals of passive gear placement. Fundamentals of 
active gear placement. Extending Gear. Judging rock quality.  

Duration: 2 hrs. 

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 4 people.

Prerequisites: None

### Leading Traditional Climbs
Description: So now you've honed your placements into a natural skill, and
you're ready to step up and become a real leader. This course will take you
through that process. You will  have the opportunity to lead through a 
progression of at least 3 climbs: 
1.  Practice lead with toprope backup. 
2.  Practice lead with fixed gear backup. 
3.  Practice lead with no backup.

Course Topics: Appropriate Stances for placement. Risk assessment. Fall 
forces on gear. 

Duration: 5 hrs.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 2 people.

Prerequisites: Traditional Gear Placement,
                      Lead Climbing (Natural Rock) or equivalent,
                      Movement Practice (Natural Rock) strongly recommended. 

### Traditional Climbing Practice
Description: A full day of traditional lead climbing practice.

Duration: 7 hrs.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 4 people.

Prerequisites: Leading Traditional Climbs

### Traditional Gear Anchors
Description: This course is designed to teach you all the skills necessary to 
build your own anchors out of traditional gear. It is for people interested in 
completing multi-pitch climbs or who would like to climb in back-country 
or unexplored areas.

Course Topics: Various use cases and choosing appropriate anchor setups. 
Assessing fall forces and direction of fall. Building solid anchors according to 
SARENE principles. Various anchor ties. Rappelling from gear anchors. 

Duration: 3 hours.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 5 people.

Prerequisites: Simple Anchors and Rappelling,
                     Traditional Gear Placement

### Advanced Nutcraft
Description: Sometimes the features in the rock do not conform to textbook 
placements. This practical course teaches you skills for those situations. 

Course Topics: Offset nut placements. Opposing nuts and Horizontal nut 
placements. Stacking nut placements. Tricam and Hex placements. 

Duration: 2 hours.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 3 people.

Prerequisites: Traditional Gear Placement

### Multi-pitch Climbing
Description: Get ready for longer adventures. This course teaches the basics of
climbing multi-pitch climbs, and is your platform to learn the skills necessary to 
climb tall routes at international destinations.

Course Topics: Building and judging integrity of belay stations. Swinging and
swapping leads. Rope Management. 2 multi-pitch climbs.

Duration: 5 hours.

Location: Long Dong

Enrollment: Maximum 2 people.

Prerequisites: Leading Traditional Climbs,
                     Traditional Gear Anchors

Disclaimer: 
While all the information available on this website is written by and reviewed 
by knowledgeable and competent guides. We can not know how you are 
applying this knowledge.Therefore we absolutely can not guarantee your 
safety. Safety is situational. Please find a qualified and competent instructor 
or guide if you wish to learn climbing.
